body.p: These are the ancient names that appear in this website. Unless otherwise noted, all the people's names are of Akkadian origin.
body.esp:glossary-list:
Iraqi archaeologist and former Director of Mosul Museum, who led archaeological excavation and restoration of the Northwest Palace in 1971-4.
AD 1931-2012. Iraqi archaeologist who directed Iraqi excavations in Nimrud, 1959-60, concentrating on the throneroom of the Northwest Palace", which Mallowan's team had not wanted to do. Weather god, of storms and beneficial rains. See the entry for Iškur/Adad on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website for more details.
"O Adad, protect the name!": Esarhaddon's chief exorcist, member of the prominent scribal family descended from Gabbu-ilani-ereš.
"Adad is my ally": king of Assyria, r.911-891 BC. Son and successor of Aššur-dan II; succeeded by Tukulti-Ninurta II.
"Adad is my ally": king of Assyria, r.810-783 BC. Son and successor of Šamši-Adad V; father of Shalmaneser IV and Aššur-dan III.
"Adda is my help" (Aramaic name): king of Damascus who led an anti-Assyrian coalition during the reign of Shalmaneser III.
Sea between Turkey and Greece, and the islands and mainlands that surround it.
"Little brother" (West Semitic name): ruler of Bit-Adini, an Aramean kingdom situated in northern Syria to east of the Euphrates. Ahunu had been a vassal of Assurnasirpal II but rebelled against Assyria on the accession of Shalmaneser III. Shalmaneser captured Ahunu's capital, Til-Barsip, and renamed it Kar-Shalmaneser. Ahunu fled across the Euphrates but was eventually defeated by Shalmaneser, who deported him to Assyria.
Senior Iraqi politician and diplomat, Director-General of Antiquities, 1944-58.
AD 1882-1968. Eminent educator, politician and promoter of Arab nationalism, who became Iraq's first non-European Director-General of Antiquities, 1934-41.
Iraqi archaeologist who directed excavations in the Northwest Palace" at Nimrud, 1975-77. His finds inlcuded a large cache of ivories in Well AJ.
Mountain range to the east of modern-day Iskanderun in Turkey, running parallel to the northern Mediterranean coast.
"The West", Assyrian name for northern Syria and the Levant.
Roughly, the western two-thirds of modern-day Turkey excluding Istanbul and its surroundings.
AD 1875–1956. German archaeologist. Excavated at Babylon in 1899 with Robert Koldewey, using new stratigraphic techniques. Excavated at Assur between 1903-14. Briefly visited Nimrud.
The sky god, worshipped especially in Uruk. See the page about An/Anu on the Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website for more information.
Mythical demon, half lion and half eagle, who stole the Tablet of Destinies but was defeated by the god Ninurta. See the page on Anzu for more details.
In ancient times, the mountainous region to the north of Assyria, between Anatolia and the Caspian Sea.
Constellation including the star now called Sirius, these days considered part of the constellation Canis Major. An island city in Phoenicia; classical Aradus, off modern Tartus in Syria.
(meaning unknown): Queen of Assyria, wife of Sargon II, buried in the Northwest Palace at Kalhu.
Major Assyrian city and provincial capital; modern Erbil, capital of Iraqi Kurdistan.
An Assyrian provincial capital just east of Assur; modern Kirkuk.
An Assyrian city on the Tigris river, the original capital and ancestral home of the royal family and many Assyrian nobles, now the archaeological site of Qalaat Sherqat. Aššur-bani-apli, "Aššur is the creator of brothers": King of Assyria (r.668-630? BC). Son and successor of Esarhaddon; father of Aššur-etel-ilani and Sin-šarru-iškun. For more detail see the page on Assurbanipal on the Knowledge and Power website. Aššur-naṣir-apli, "Aššur is the protector of the heir": King of Assyria (r.1049–1031 BC). Son and successor of Šamši-Adad IV; father of Shalmaneser II and Aššur-rabi II.
Aššur-naṣir-apli, "Aššur is the protector of the heir". King of Assyria, (r.883-859 BC). Founder of Kalhu as the capital of the Assyrian empire and father of king Shalmaneser III. See the article on Assurnasirpal.
The national god of Assyria and embodiment of the city of Assur. For more detail, see the page on Aššur.
"Aššur is the lord of all": king of Assyria, r.1073–1056 BC. Son and successor of Tiglath-pileser I.
"O Aššur, strengthen the heir!": Son of Shalmaneser III who led a major revolt against his father.
"Aššur is the prince of the gods": King of Assyria (r.630?-623? BC), who ruled from Nineveh. Son and successor of Assurbanipal and brother of his successor, Sin-šarru-iškun.
Better, Aššur-šimanni, "O Aššur, hear me!": scribe and eponym official of Tiglath-pileser I, who wrote a dedication to Tašmetu at Assur.
"O Aššur, strengthen your yoke!": chief cup-bearer of king Assurnasirpal II.
"Aššur is my helper": chief priest at Ninurta's temple in Kalhu during the reign of Esarhaddon.
"O Aššur I have grasped my name!": scribe in the royal palace at Assur during the reign of Tiglath-pileser I; an early devotee of the god Nabu.
"Aššur brought him to life": king of Assyria, r.1365-1330 BC. Founder of the Middle Assyrian empire.
Sumerian name for a powerful stone demon defeated by the god Ninurta; Akkadian asakku.
"Lord" (West Semitic name): king of Tyre in the early seventh century, defeated by king Esarhaddon.
"The Babylonian": Royal exorcist in late ninth-century Kalhu; member of the scholarly Ištaran-šumu-ukin family. Grandson of Ištaran-mudammiq, father of Marduk-[...].
Goddess and spouse of the god Zababa, with several cult centres in Assyria; also written as Bau or Babu. See the page about Baba on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website for more details.
"Baba has given a name": astrologer at Kalhu during the reign of Assurbanipal.
The most important city of Babylonia, near the modern Iraqi city of Hilla.
The territory to the south of the Assyrian heartland, formerly an independent polity and constantly reclaiming that independence from Assyria. For more detail, see the page about Babylonia on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
AD 1815–1888. British missionary and Arabic scholar, who worked across the Middle East as a teacher and translator. Worked in the region around Mosul between 1842 and 1844, accompanied by Rev James Phillips Fletcher.
Modern capital city of Iraq, formerly a provincial capital of the Ottoman empire. Did not exist in antiquity; founded in AD 762.
An abbreviated name containing either the element "alive" or "life": member of staff at Ezida in Kalhu in the late seventh century, exact function unknown.
Site of the ancient city of Imgur-Ellil.
"Creatress": Queen of Assyria, wife of Shalmaneser V.
"Little son" (West Semitic name): exorcist with no known family affiliation working at Kalhu and Nineveh during the 7th century BC.
Modern city at the head of the Gulf in southern Iraq, formerly a provincial capital of the Ottoman empire. Did not exist in antiquity; founded in AD 636.
"Lord", a name of the god Marduk.
"Bel has created": Ruler of Babylon, placed on the throne by king Sennacherib and promptly removed by him again in 700 BC after a failed attempt to gain independence.
"Bel-tarṣi is god": Governor of Kalhu and eponym official during the reign of Adad-nerari III, c.808–793 BC. A eunuch, he dedicated a statue to the king in Nabu's temple and probably lived in the large residence opposite the temple. Shown on BSAI's plan as "GOVERNOR'S PALACE".
"Bel has assembled": astrologer and senior scholar of king Sennacherib, still ative in Esarhaddon's reign.
AD 1868–1926. British traveller, archaeologist and administrator, heavily involved in the creation of Mandate Iraq and founder of the Iraq Museum in Baghdad in the early 1920s. The British School of Archaeology in Iraq was created in her memory.
AD 1813–1885. Egyptologist and, from 1866, Keeper of Oriental Antiquities in the British Museum; co-founder of the Society for Biblical Archaeology in 1870.
Aramean kingdom with capital Til-Barsip, situated in northern Syria to the east of the Euphrates; conquered and integrated into Assyria under Shalmaneser III.
AD 1951-2004. British Assyriologist who worked for the BSAI in Iraq in the 1980s and was later appointed Lecturer in Assyriology at the University of Oxford (1988-2004). He completed Donald Wiseman's work on the scholarly tablets from Nabu's temple in Nimrud.
Former name of the city of Mumbai on the northwest coast of India. It was an important trade port for the East India Company. It was renamed in 1996.
City a few kilometres southwest of Babylon cult centre of the god Nabu.
AD 1802–1870. French consul at Mosul and natural historian who excavated the palace of Sargon II at Dur-Šarruken in 1843.
AD 1814-1900. Artist who worked alongside Austen Henry Layard, and later William Kennett Loftus, at Nineveh and Nimrud in the 1850s.
AD 1857–1934. Egyptologist and Assyriologist who worked for the British Museum, serving as its Keeper of Oriental Antiquities, 1894-1924.
AD 1786–1855. British traveller and author, who journeyed in the Middle East extensively between 1813 and 1818, and visited Nimrud in 1816.
Large official building west of Nabu's temple in Kalhu, excavated by William Kennett Loftus in 1854 and again by the BSAI in the 1950s. It was occupied from at least the Middle Assryrian period to after the end of empire. Loftus found a large number of the Nimrud ivories and letters addressed to king Sargon II in the throne room. Shown on BSAI's plan.
"Son of Zinanu" (West Semitic name): court physician at Kalhu in the early eighth century.
Region north of the modern Iraqi town of Dohuk. "Man from Birtu": court physician at Kalhu in the early eighth century.
Classical name for a Phoenician city on the eastern Mediterranean coast, Assyrian Gubla, modern Ğubail in Lebanon.
AD 1786-1880. British ambassador to the Ottoman empire in Constantinople, 1825–8 and 1841–58; supporter of Layard's work at Nimrud.
Major city and provincial capital of Assyria, situated on the Euphrates on the modern-day border between Turkey and Syria.
Built by king Tiglath-pileser III, south of the Northwest Palace in Kalhu; its bas-reliefs were later re-used for king Esarhaddon's new Southwest Palace. Its meagre remains were investigated several times in the nineteenth century but it was not until the 1970s that Janusz Meuszyński's team systematically excavated it. Shown on BSAI's plan.
Eminent Iraqi politician under the British Mandate, holding several different cabinet posts.
AD 1890-1976. World-famous detective novelist and wife of Sir Max Mallowan. Member of the BSAI expedition to Nimrud in the 1950s.
AD 1789-1854. British politician and keen amateur antiquarian, who visited Nimrud in 1850
Provincial capital, Assyrian Kummuhi; modern Samsat in Turkey (now flooded by the Ataturk Dam).
Former name of the city of Istanbul in Turkey. Although the Ottomans formally changed its name to Istanbul in the 1450s AD, the old name Constantinople continued in use, especially in English, until the creation of the modern Turkish state in 1923.
AD 1810-80. British artist who worked alongside Austen Henry Layard on his second expedition to Nimrud, 1849-51.
Large island in the Mediterranean, demarcating the southern limits of the Aegean cultural zone.
Island in the northeastern Mediterranean, split into several kingdoms whose rulers were Assyrian vassals. For more detail, see the page about Cyprus on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Achaemenid king of Persia, conquerer of Babylonia, r.539–530 BC.
Grain god from the eastern Mediterranean; see the page about Dagan on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
Assyrian provincial capital, formerly the capital of an independent kingdom and now the capital of modern-day Syria.
The spouse of the great god Ea, worshipped especially at Kalhu.
"Aššur is judge": vizier of king Shalmaneser III.
(meaning unknown): (chief) firewood supplier to Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the late seventh century.
AD 1815–1877. French consul in Baghdad, 1861–64, who undertook excavations at Nimrud and Babylon, sending material to the Louvre, Paris.
The northernmost region of Egypt, where the river Nile fans out into many small rivers forming a large estuary to the Mediterranean. In antiquity, this area often had its own political and cultural characteristics.
City in northeastern Babylonia, now Tell Aqar; ancestral home of the Ištaran-šumu-ukin family of scholars.
AD 1812-70. British journalist and novelist whose writings did much to create the modern image of Christmas.
Tributary of the Tigris river, whose headwaters lie in the Zagros mountains of western Iran, flowing southwestward in order to join the Tigris below Baghdad. Its Assyrian name was Turna.
AD 1871-1934. British imperial administrator who served as High Commissioner for Iraq, 1923-8, the most senior representative of British government under the Mandate.
"Fort Sargon": city founded and built by king Sargon II, which replaced Kalhu as the Assyrian king's main residence. Sennacherib moved the capital to Nineveh in the early seventh century bu Dur-Šarruken remained a provincial capital. For more information see the page on Dur-Šarruken at the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
God of wisdom, magic, and incantations. For a general overview of this deity, see the page on Enki/Ea at the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
"House of heaven" temple of the goddess Ištar in Uruk.
"Ea-the-king", the great god Ea as worshipped at Kalhu.
Mid-third millennium city and kingdom in Syria, c.55 km southeast of modern Aleppo.
In the 8th and 7th centuries BC, Egypt was politically fragmented, with the rulers of Kush, various local dynasts in the Delta region, as well as occasional Assyrian kings, trying to claim sovereignty over the region. There was a sizeable Egyptian community in Assyria at this time.
"Mountain house", the temple of Ellil in Nippur; also a name of Aššur's temple in Assur.
Iraqi archaeologist and Director-General of Antiquities in the mid-1960s, under whom the new Iraq Museum was opened in 1966.
Kingdom in southwestern Iran, centred on the city of Susa, often in conflict with Assyria.
"My god is Yahweh" (Hebrew name): Biblical prophet who features in the Old Testament Book of Kings.
"My god is salvation" (Hebrew name): Biblical prophet and follower of Elijah who features in the Old Testament Book of Kings.
Head of the Sumerian pantheon, and still one of the most important gods in Neo-Assyrian times when he was often likened to the god Aššur.
Kingdom in the Zagros mountains of western Iran.
Small town at the southern end of the eastern Mediterranean coast and site of a battle in 701 BC between king Sennacherib's Assyrian army and Taharqa's Egyptian forces, at which the Assyrians claimed victory.
"House that lifts its head", the temple of the god Marduk in Babylon.
Aššur-ahu-iddina, "Aššur has given a brother": king of Assyria (r.680-669 BC). Son and successor of Sennacherib; father of Assurbanipal and Šamaš-šumu-ukin. See the page on Esarhaddon at the Knowledge and Power website.
"House of the Universe", the temple of the supreme god Aššur in the city of Assu
Main temple of Ninurta at Nippur.
Region of western Italy north of Rome, home of Etruscan culture in the 9th-6th centuries BC.
Major river running through the western part of Mesopotamia, some 2,800 km long, which rises in the Taurus mountains and in Assyrian times flowed directly into the Persian Gulf.
"True house", the temple of the god Nabu at Kalhu. See the page on Ezida. Also, and originally, the name of Nabu's temple in the Babylonian city of Borsippa. Shown on BSAI's plan as "Nabu Temple (Ezida)".
AD 1885-1933. King of Iraq, 1921-33. The monarchy was created by the British Mandate in order to lessen the appearance of direct rule while creating a state that was structurally familiar to the British establishment. Faisal was chosen as the most suitable candidate and strongly supported by Gertrude Bell. He was succeeded by his only son, Ghazi (r.1933-7).
AD 1935–1958. King of Iraq, 1939–58. Grandson of king Faisal I, who came to the throne at the age of three on his father Ghazi's death in a car crash. Ghazi's brother-in-law 'Abd al-Illah ruled as regent until 1953, when Faisal turned 18. Both men were assassinated in 1958, bringing Iraq's short-lived, British-imposed monarchy to an end.
AD 1952–2011. Italian archaeologist, who directed excavations at Nimrud with the Centro Ricerche Archeologiche e Scavi di Torino in 1987–9.
British missionary, accompanied the Rev. George Badger to Mosul in 1842. Visited Nimrud in 1844 and dug for inscribed bricks there.
"All gods have desired": senior scholar of Tukulti-Ninurta II and Assurnasirpal II; ancestor of a famous family of royal scholars.
AD 1893–1969. Assyriologist and British Museum curator. Worked on joint British-US excavations at Ur under Leonard Woolley in 1923, and at Nimrud under Max Mallowan in 1952. WIth his book The Stones of Assyria (1936) he was the first to track the movements of the sculptures excavated from the Northwest Palace in the nineteenth century.
"The boss-eyed one": steward of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the late seventh century.
"Locust" (Arabic name): leader of an Arab tribe in the Syrian desert; adversary of king Shalmaneser III.
Small kingdom in the Zagros mountains east of Muṣaṣir and immediately south of Lake Van.
Tributary of the Tigris river, about 400 km long. It rises near Lake Van in modern Turkey (ancient Urartu) and joins the Tigris 10km south of Nimrud.
AD 1801-82. German engraver, appointed "art advisor" to British queen Victoria in 1845, who worked on some of the illustrations for Layard's books on Nimrud.
Sumerian "Great One", goddess of healing and patron of Assyrian court physicians. See the entry for Gula/Ninkarrak on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website for more details.
An archaic term for the tribes of the Zagros mountains.
Former capital of the Syrian kingdom of the same name and, following its integration into Assyria under Tiglath-pileser III, part of the Assyrian province of Manṣuate; Biblical Hamath, modern Hama.
Queen of Assyria, wife of king Shalmaneser IV, who was buried in the Northwest Palace at Kalhu.
District subject to the Assyrian provincial governor of Kalhu, location unknown.
Better, Haza-il, "God has seen" (West Semitic name): king of Damascus (d.796 BC) who is mentioned several times in the biblical Book of Kings and features on the Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III.
Ancient Greek historian (c.484-425 BC) who wrote about Assyria, and other parts of the Middle East, in his famous book The Histories.
AD 1792–1866. Irish clergyman and one of the pioneer decipherers of cuneiform script.
Iraqi archaeologist and director of excavations at Nimrud since 1985. In 1985-7 he led a project to re-excavate and restore Nabu's temple. In 1988-91 he discovered the famous queens' tombs and their gold treasure underthe southern end of the Northwest Palace, and later worked on Ištar's temple at the north end of the acropolis.
"Gazelle": senior administrator of the god Ištaran's temple in Der, c.900 BC, and grandfather of the Kalhu scholar Ištaran-mudammiq.
"Jahweh is he" (Hebrew name); also Yahua or Jehu, king of Israel (r.c.842-815 BC) who is mentioned several times in the biblical Book of Kings and features on the Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III.
Small town about 25 kilometres to the northwest of Kalhu whose main claim to fame are enormous gates with decorative bronze bands commissioned by king Assurnasirpal II for the temple of the dream god Mamu. These are now known as the Balawat Gates, after the modern name of the archaeological site.
River that flows 2880 km southwest from pakistan to northwestern India, home to a major civilisation that dates back to the fourth millennium BC
Ancient term for mainland Greece.
"God is true, reliable" (Hurrian name): king of Hamat in Syria during the reign of Shalmaneser III.
Small town in northern Assyria.
Ancient Israel was known to the Assyrians after its founder as Bit-Humri, "House of Omri". For more information see the page on Israel at the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Goddess of war, love and beauty, worshipped at Kalhu as Ištar šarrat niphi, "Ištar, Blazing Queen" and Ištar bēlet kidmūri "Ištar, Mistress of the Kidmuru". For a general overview of this deity, see the page on Inana/Ištar at the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
"Ištar has desired a name": Assurbanipal's senior scholar; an important figure in the inner circle of both Esarhaddon and especially Assurbanipal, he was a member of the prominent Assyrian scribal family descended from Gabbu-ilani-ereš.
Babylonian god worshipped especially at Der. For more information see the page on Ištaran on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
"Ištaran is the one who gives fortune": king Assurnasirpal II's senior exorcist and a member of the Ištaran-šumu-ukin family of scholars.
"Ištaran has firmly established the name": Babylonian ancestor of an eminent family of Assyrian royal scholars of the ninth to early eighth centuries BC.
Governor of the Ottoman province of Mosul, 1809 and 1812-1818. The Jalili family had had a virtual monopoly on this position since the early eighteenth century.
AD 1862–1936. Academic and author, director of the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambrige, 1893-1908 and later Provost of Eton College. Most famous as a writer of ghost stories.
AD 1813–1878. Officer in the East India Company's navy. He led several map-making surveys of Mesopotamia in the 1840s, looking for viable river routes to India, during which he discovered and mapped many important archaeolocial sites. He served as the EIC's Resident in Baghdad, later political agent to the British government, 1854-64.
Phoenician settlement on the eastern Mediterrean coast between Arwad in the north and Sidon in the south; exact location unknown.
"Dog(sbody)/Servant": senior scholar of king Sennacherib, who fell out of favour through trying to deceive the king with falsely positive omens.
One aspect of the goddess Ištar as worshipped at Kalhu is bēlet kidmūri, "Mistress of the divine Kidmuru". The name Kidmuru does not occur in any other context so it is difficult to determine exactly what it means; it is possible that it is a collective name for a group of gods.
AD 1869-19. British Assyriologist at the British Museum whose work on the royal inscriptions from Nimrud (amongst many other works) proved an invaluable resource for understanding Assyrian history.
Northern Babylonian city, modern Tell Ingharra, excavated by a joint Oxford-Chicago team under the Mandate
Archaeological site of the ancient Assyrian city Dur-Šarruken.
AD 1855–1925. German architect and archaeologist. Led excavations at Babylon in 1899, using new stratigraphic techniques to study mud-brick structures.
Assyrian province situated between the northern stretches of the Orontes river and the Mediterranean coast. The capital city of the same name is at the modern archaeological site of Tell Tayinat.
Nubia, a kingdom to the south of Egypt in modern Sudan. See the page on Kush at the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Modern name of the archaeological site that is the citadel of Nineveh; also spelled Koujunjik.
AD 1817–94. English adventurer and later politician and diplomat who as a young man discovered the ruins of Nimrud and Nineveh. His explorations and excavations there in the 1840s made ancient Assyria (and himself) famous worldwide.
"The one who does not see the god": Prophet from Arbela, communicating the words of Ištar to king Esarhaddon.
Mountain range near the east coast of the Mediterranean, famous for its cedar forests.
The lands of the eastern Mediterranean, roughly equivalent to modern-day Syria, Lebanon, Israel, Palestine, and Jordan.
AD 1902-96. British archaeologist who served as advisor to Iraq's Directorate-General of Antiquities, 1939-48.
AD 1821–58. British traveller who explored many Mesopotamian sites, including Nimrud, Ur, and Uruk, between 1849 and 1855, bringing back ancient objects for the British Museum and publishing a volume of cuneiform texts.
Slave given to Nabu's temple in Kalhu by Nabu-sakip in the late seventh century BC.
Phoenician settlement on the eastern Mediterrean coast between Arwad in the north and Sidon in the south; exact location unknown.
Phoenician settlement on the eastern Mediterrean coast between Arwad in the north and Sidon in the south; exact location unknown.
AD 1812–94. Swiss-British scholar of the Bible and Asian languages who travelled widely in India and the Middle East. Layard's book Discoveries in Nineveh and Babylon (1853) includes sketches by Malan of the 1850 season at Nimrud.
AD 1904–78. British archaeologist who directed the British School of Archaeology in Iraq, 1947–59 and led its expedition to Nimrud; married first to Agatha Christie and then to the Assyriologist Barbara Parker.
Dream god with a temple at Imgur-Ellil, for which king Assurnasirpal II commissioned the magnificent Balawat Gates.
AD 1894-1976. German architect of the Iraq Museum, opened in 1966; more famous for the design of the Berlin Olympic Stadium opened for the infamous Olympic Games of 1936.
Supreme god of Babylon, where he was worshipped at the temple Esaggila; father of the god Nabu.
Royal scribe and senior scholar of king Adad-nerari III; son of Babilayu, descendant of Ištaran-šumu-ukin.
"O Marduk, protect the heir!": Ruler of the small kingdom Suhu during the reign of Shalmaneser III.
"Marduk is the lord of help": rebellious brother of the Babylonian king Marduk-zakir-šumi.
"Marduk is the establisher of the name": king Assurbanipal's chief exorcist; successor of Adad-šumu-uṣur, with whom he worked closely in the earlier stage of his career.
"O Marduk protect the king!": Priest of Nabu's temple in late 7th-century Kalhu.
"Marduk has named an heir": king of Babylon, ally of Shalmaneser III and Šamši-Adad V.
née Rachel Clay, AD 1914-2011. British archaeologist and key member of the BSAI's team at Nimrud in the 1950s.
A region in the Zagros mountains of western Iran. For more detail, see the page about the Medes on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
AD 1946-76. Polish archaeologist, director of the project to excavate the Central Palace at Nimrud, 1974-6.
"Man from Meluhha": senior scholar of king Shalmaneser III.
AD 1869-1940. Scottish graphic artist best known for his book illustrations, including many works by E. Nesbit.
Northern Iraqi city in on the opposite bank of the Tigris to Nineveh; provincial capital of the Ottoman empire and now the main base for Iraqi archaeologists and historians of Nimrud.
The divine consort of the supreme god Aššur; see the page about Ninlil/Mullissu on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website for more details.
"Mullissu is the one who unites Nineveh": queen of Assyria, wife of Assurnasirpal II and mother of Shalmaneser III; she may have been buried in the Northwest Palace at Kalhu.
AD 1913–81. British archaeologist; Lecturer in Oriental History and Archaeology at the University of Cambridge, 1949-81.
Small independent state in the Zagros region, a former ally of king Sargon II and captured by him in 712 BC; a religious centre of great influence from at least the early second millennium BC and one of the most important temples for the rulers of Urartu. Archaeological site of Mudjesir near Rowanduz.
"Borderland", probably a country far to the east of Assyria during the reign of Shalmaneser III; or perhaps Egypt (which was usually called Muṣur by the Assyrians).
God of wisdom and patron of scribes and scholars, son of the great Babylonian deity Marduk with a large temple in Kalhu. For more detail see the page on Nabu.
"Nabu has given a brother": (chief) firewood supplier of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the late seventh century BC.
"Nabu has replaced the brothers": steward of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the late seventh century BC.
"Nabu has given an heir": one of the senior scholars of king Sennacherib in around 700 BC.
"Nabu has replaced": lamentation priest of Ninurta's temple in Kalhu, accused of theft by a colleague.
"Nabu is my rescue":
"O Nabu, protect my steps!"
"O Nabu, protect my heir!": presumably a member of the cultic staff at Nabu's temple in Kalhu, as he reported to the king on a ritual for Tašmetu.
"Nabu is almighty": scribe of a scholarly tablet found in Nabu's temple in Kalhu; son of the royal lamenter Urad-Ea.
"Nabu is the one who gives fortune": royal exorcist, descendant of Ištaran-šumu-ukin and son of Ištaran-mudammiq; copyist or owner of one of the scholarly tablets found in Nabu's temple in Kalhu.
"Nabu is exalted: one of the domestic staff in Nabu's temple in Kalhu, exact title unknown.
"Nabu is the giver of the name": royal exorcist in Kalhu and Nineveh during the reign of Esarhaddon.
Better, Nabu-sagib "Nabu is exalted": donor of two slaves to Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the mid-seventh century BC.
"O Nabu, keep the brothers safe!": scribe who dedicated a mace-head to Nabu's temple in Kalhu.
"O Nabu, keep them safe!": king Sargon II's chief scribe and senior scholar, author of the famous Letter to Aššur.
"Nabu has given a name"; also known as Nadinu, "Giver": "mayor" of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the early seventh century BC; also monitors horses arriving at Fort Shalmaneser, sending regular reports to the king.
"Nabu has created the name": physician in Kalhu in the early eighth century BC.
"O Nabu, protect the name!": chief priest of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the late seventh century.
"O Nabu, let the seed prosper!": king Esarhaddon's chief scribe; member of the eminent Gabbu-ilani-ereš family of scholars.
"O Nabu, keep the true one upright!": member of the eminent Gabbu-ilani-ereš family of scholars in Kalhu during the reigns of Sargon and Sennacherib.
River in modern-day Lebanon which runs for 30km into the Mediterranean sea. Rulers, ancient and modern, have traditionally erected monuments at its mouth.
A name of Ištar in her aspect as goddess of love
(meaning unknown): steward of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the late seventh century BC.
"The pure one" (Aramaic name), also called Zakutu, which is the same name in Akkadian: Queen of Assyria, wife of Sennacherib and mother of Esarhaddon. As queen mother she was particularly influential.
Arabic "Prophet Jonah", a mound just south of Kuyunjik in Nineveh, where the Old Testament prophet is said to be buried. See the page on the Knowledge and Power website for more details.
God of destructive force and animal instincts; lord of the Underworld. For more information see the page about Nergal on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses site.
"Nergal is my god": Adad-nerari III’s commander-in-chief, who dedicated a large inscribed weight-stone to the goddess Tašmetu in Kalhu.
"Nergal is our king": chief priest of Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the early seventh century.
AD 1858-1924. British author, remembered especially for her children's books. Her The Story of the Amulet features a visit to ancient Babylon and an encounter with Nisroch.
Assyrian province and its capital city of the same name, on the banks of the river Tigris, opposite the modern-day city of Mosul in northern Iraq. One of the most important cities of northern Mesopotamia from the 3rd millennium BC, it was the main residence of the Assyrian kings from the reign of Sennacherib onwards. For more information, see the page about Nineveh on the Knowledge and Power website.
Spouse of the god Ellil, Babylonian counterpart of the Assyrian goddess Mullissu. For more information, see the page about Ninlil on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
Biblical name of the god Ninurta and the origin of the modern site name Nimrud.
God of victory, originally worshipped in Nippur. King Assurnasirpal erected a fine temple for Ninurta in Kalhu. For more information, see the page about Ninurta.
City in central Babylonia, near modern Nuffar.
Alternatively, Nissaba or Nidaba, goddess of grain and writing. See her page on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
Originally a Biblical corruption of Nimrod, in the 19th century this name became attached to the winged genie sculptures from the Northwest Palace.
Another name for Kush.
Another name for the god Ea.
God of light and hope, son of the moongod Sin. For more information see the Nuska/Nusku on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
AD 1927–2004. British archaeologist, Director of BSAI excavations at Nimrud in 1958–62, focusing on Fort Shalmaneser. Married to archaeologist Joan Oates (née Lines).
Large palace in Assur, built in the early second millennium BC, where later the kings of Assyria were buried.
"The Lord is my life" (Hebrew name): king of Israel in the ninth century BC and founder of a dynasty known to the Assyrians as "the house of Omri".
British archaeologist, David Oates' successor as Director of BSAI excavations at Nimrud, 1963.
Major river in the Levant, running from the springs in the Beqaa Valley between Lebanon and Anti-Lebanon to the north through Syria into Turkey.
AD 1941-2010. American archaeologist who specialised in the virtual reconstruction of the Northwest Palace at Nimrud.
"He has saved the god-fearing": Slave given to Nabu's temple in Kalhu by Nabu-sakip in the late seventh century BC.
"May I see Aššur's face!": eunuch of Sargon II.
Minor god, often seen as the minister of Anu. See his page on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website
Lady Mallowan, AD 1908–93. British archaeologist and Assyriologist. Founding member of theBritish School of Archaeology in Iraq and epigrapher for its Nimrud excavations; lecturer in Mesopotamian archaeology at the Institute of Archaeology in London. Married Max Mallowan after Agatha Christie's death in 1977.
Region in southern Turkey, on the east Mediterranean coast; ruled by king Qarparunda at the time of Shalmaneser III in the mid-9th century BC.
AD 1820–68. British painter known particularly for his portraits (including one of Layard) and for his Biblical scenes.
A group of city-states along the north of the east Mediterranean coast, including Sidon and Tyre. For more details, see the page about the Phoenicians on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
"Corner-stone": Lamenter of Nabu's temple in Kalhu during the reigns of Esarhaddon and Assurbanipal.
Modern name of the archaeological site of Assur. Men from the local Sherqati tribe are renowned as expert excavators and are employed on digs across Iraq and Syria.
Royal city of Irhuleni, king of Hamat, on the Orontes river.
Ruler of Patina on the southeast coast of Turkey, who paid tribute to king Shalmaneser III.
Assyrian province and its capital of the same name, encompassing the southeastern corner of the Turkish coast around the modern city of Adana (classical Cilicia).
Ruler of a small kingdom in Media who swore to uphold king Esarhaddon's succession treaty in the early 7th century BC.
Egyptian pharaoh of the Nineteenth Dynasty, 13th century BC, who expanded Egypt's territorial control far into the Levant as well as into Kush and modern-day Libya.
AD 1826-1910. Mosul-born archaeologist, who worked first with Layard and then independently for the British Museum at Nimrud and other Mesopotamian archaeological sites.
AD 1810-95. British employee of the East India Company, posted to Baghdad in 1845 as its senior official there. Did much to support Layard's work at Nimrud and was actively involved in the first decipherments of cuneiform script.
AD 1794-1872. British portrait painter and expert on mezzotint engraving.
AD 1786/7-1821. British employee of the East India Company, posted to Baghdad in 1808 as its resident there. His antiquarian interests led him to write two books on the ruins of Babylon and a long account of travel in Kurdistan and the area around Nimrud. The British Museum bought some of his collection of Mesopotamian and other antiquities after his death.
AD 1864-1930. American Assyriologist who wrote an influential book on the history of Babylonia and Assyria published in 1900.
AD 1915-83. American Assyriologist, mostly known for his work on Babylonian mathematics and astronomy, who pieced together some of Esarhaddon's succession treaties in the British Museum.
Assyrian province and its centre of the same name; now Zincirli in modern Turkey.
"The god Sammu is exalted/beloved" (West Semitic name): late ninth-century queen of Assyria, wife of Šamši-Adad V and mother of Adad-nerari III. A powerful woman in her own right, on whom the legendary figure of Semiramis was later based.
(meaning unknown): royal diviner in the reign of Adad-nerari III who witnessed a legal document.
Legendarily decadent last king of Assyria, in classical Greek and later traditions, perhaps an amalgam of Assurbanipal and his brother Šamaš-šumu-ukin.
Šarru-kenu, "The king is true": king of Assyria (r.721-705 BC) who ascended to the throne in suspicious circumstances following the death of his (half-)brother, Shalmaneser V, and who died in battle in Anatolia; eponym official of the year 719 BC. See the page about Sargon on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Legendarily impressive queen of Assyria, in classical Greek and later traditions, most likely based on Sammu-ramat.
Sin-ahhe-eriba, "Sin has replaced the brothers": king of Assyria (r. 704-681 BC); son of Sargon II and father of Esarhaddon. See the page about Sennacherib on the Knowledge and Power website.
Large lake of some 940 km2, high in the mountains of central eastern Armenia.
Salmanu-ašared, "The god Salmanu is foremost": king of Assyria (r.782–773 BC), who ruled from Kalhu.
Salmanu-ašared, "The god Salmanu is the foremost": king of Assyria (r.726-722 BC), crown prince of Assyria (as Ululaya) under his father Tiglath-pileser III; (half-)brother of Sargon II, his successor; eponym official of the year 723 BC. See the page about Shalmaneser V on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Salmanu-ašared, "The god Salmanu is foremost": king of Assyria, who ruled from Kalhu (r.858-824 BC); son of king Assurnasirpal II and father of king Šamši-Adad V. See the page about Shalmaneser III.
(meaning unknown, Kushite name): pharaoh of Kush (r.721-706 BC), contemporary and sometime enemy of Sargon II.
Modern name of the archaological site of ancient Tarbiṣu, 5 km northwest of Nineveh.
"Seven", a group of seven gods equated with the constellation Pleiades, who had a temple dedicated to them in Kalhu.
An Assyrian provincial capital on the eastern Mediterranean coast; Assyrian Ṣidunu, now Saida in modern Lebanon.
The moon-god; the moon. See the page about Nanna/Suen/Sin on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
"Sin has established the king": king of Assyria (r. 624-612 BC) under whom the Medes and Babylonians attacked and captured much of the heartland of empire and preciptated its final collapse.
District subject to the Assyrian provincial governor of Kalhu, location unknown.
AD 1840-73, British Assyriologist, employed by the British Museum, who deciphered many of the Assyrian cuneiform tablets found at Nimrud and Kuyunjik, most famously the so-called "Flood tablet" of the Epic of Gilgamesh.
Polish architect on Meuszyński's archaeological expedition to Nimrud in the 1970s who later worked with Sam Paley on the virtual reconstruction of the Northwest Palace.
Palace built by king Sennacherib on the royal citadel at Nineveh in the early seventh century. Shown on BSAI's plan as "S W Palace".
Ruler of the tribal lands of Gilzanu in northwest Iran, a vassal state of Assyria in the ninth and eighth centuries BC.
Artificial waterway in modern Egypt, which opened in 1869. By connecting the Mediterranean with the Red Sea some 200km to the south, it allowed shipping to travel directly between Europe and the Middle East (and India) without having to travel all around Africa.
Territory on the middle Euphrates river, originally a small independent kingdom and later absorbed into the Assyrian province of Hindanu.
Southern Babylonia where Sumerian was the main written language, especially in the third millennium BC.
"Shade (protection) of Aššur": despite his Assyrian name, this man identifies himself as an Egyptian scribe when he buys a house in Nineveh.
Goddess, spouse of the god Adad, who shared a temple in Kalhu; see the page about Šala on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
The sun-god; god of justice; the sun. See the page about Utu/Šamaš on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
"Šamaš has established the name": Assyrian prince, later king of Babylon (r. 668-648 BC); son of Esarhaddon and brother of Assurbanipal, who in 652 contested his rule over Babylonia and, after a bloody war, finally wrestled power from him in 648. Thought to have died by suicide when Babylon was taken by Assyrian troops.
"My sun is Adad": king of the Old Assyrian period who conquered the city of Assur (r.c.1808-1773) and made it the capital of a large upper Mesopotamian kingdom.
"My sun is Adad": king of Assyria (r.823-811), son and successor of Shalmaneser III; father of Adad-nerari III.
"Blazing queen": aspect of the great goddess Ištar as worshipped in her temple at Kalhu.
Kingdom near the source of the Tigris river in modern Turkey; integrated into Assyria in 673 BC in the form of two provinces. For more detail, see the page about Šubria on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Abbreviation of a name containing the element "name": exorcist and son of Nabu-zeru-lešir, Esarhaddon's chief scribe; following the death of his father he petitions crown prince Assurbanipal to give him a position at Kalhu so that he may succeed his father and grandfather in royal service.
Third-millennium city in southern Mesopotamia; the modern archaeological site of Fara.
(meaning unknown, the Assyrian version of the Libyan name Shoshenq): a relative by marriage of king Sennacherib, as discussed on the page about Egyptian heiroglyphs.
Assyrian version of the Egyptian name Tarqu (meaning unknown): pharaoh of Kush (r.690-664 BC) and enemy of kings Sennacherib and Esarhaddon.
AD 1800–77. British inventor of photographic techniques, antiquarian, and amateur Assyriologist, especially in later life.
"My partner": temple administrator from the northern Babylonian city of Der, father of king Assurnasirpal II's senior exorcist Ištaran-mudammiq.
Assyrian city, 5 km northwest of Nineveh; residence of the crown prince in the seventh century BC; modern Sherif Khan.
Goddess, spouse of the god Nabu; for more information see the page about Tašmetu on the Ancient Mesopotamian Gods and Goddesses website.
Major mountain range in southeastern Turkey.
Archaeological site of ancient Kullania which in recent years has yielded important information about the easternmost parts of the Assyrian empire.
District under the control of the provincial governor of Kalhu, location unknown. -->
1876-1941. British Assyriologist and archeologist who led British Museum excavations at Nineveh, 1927-32, with the assistance of Max Mallowan.
The chaotic sea, defeated by Marduk who constructs the world from her body in The Epic of Creation.
Tukulti-apil-Ešarra, "My trust is (in) the heir of Ešarra": king of Assyria (r. 1114-1076 BC).
Tukulti-apil-Ešarra, "My trust is (in) the heir of Ešarra": king of Assyria (r.744-727 BC), who significantly expanded the empire. See the page about Tiglath-pileser III on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
Major river that runs through eastern Mesopotamia, on which the major cities of Assyria were situated. It is some 1800 km long, rising in the eastern Taurus mountains and flowing south, where it emptied directly into the Persian Gulf in Assyrian times.
Modern name for an outdoor shrine on the Tigris in Šubria, featuring three mountain caves around a spring.
Capital city of Bit-Adini and later an Assyrian provincial capital.
Area on the northeast of Nimrud citadel, where archaeologists found the remains of domestic houses in 1953. Shown on BSAI's plan as "Houses T W 53".
"My trust is (in) Ninurta": king of Assyria (r.1243-1207 BC).
"My trust is (in) Ninurta": king of Assyria (r. 890-884 BC).
British archaeologist and historian of Assyriology.
Phoenician city-state, situated on an island off the eastern Mediterranean coast; Assyrian Ṣurru, modern Ṣur in Lebanon.
City in southern Babylonia; now Tell Muqayyar.
"Servant of Ea": Lamenter in the service of Esarhaddon, with the official title "lamenter of Sin and the king"; a member of a famous family of Assyrian lamenters.
"Servant of Gula": Exorcist in the service of Esarhaddon and Assurbanipal; a member of a prominent Gabbu-ilani-ereš family, he was the son of Adad-šumu-uṣur.
"Servant of Ištar": šangû-priest at Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the mid-to-late seventh century.
"Servant of Nabu": http://oracc.org/saao/saa12/P33673 priest at Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the mid-seventh century; ; [2] slave dedicated by his uncle to Nabu's temple in 655 BC.
A kingdom to the north of Assyria between Lake Van, Lake Sevan and Lake Urmia, with capital Tušpa (or Turushpa), modern Van; Biblical Ararat, Armenia. For more detail, see the page about Urartu on the Assyrian Empire Builders website.
"Servant": cook at Nabu's temple in Kalhu in the mid-to-late seventh century BC.
Lake in what is now northwestern Iran, on the edge of ancient Urartu.
"The Urukean (goddess) is queen": Prophetess from Kalhu, communicating the words of Ištar of Arbela and Mullissu to king Esarhaddon.
City in southern Babylonia; Biblical Erech, now Warka.
"He belongs to the god Onuris" (Egyptian name): crown prince of the Kushite pharaoh Taharqa during the reign of Esarhaddon.
Lake in what is now eastern Turkey, on the edge of ancient Urartu.
1st Earl Cowley, AD 1804-1884. British diplomat; secretary and deputy of Sir Stratford Canning in Constantinople in the 1840s; later British ambassador to France, 1852-67.
AD 1838–1906. Swiss businessman and antiquarian, lived in Baghdad from 1860–68 while working for an export company. Excavated bas-reliefs at Nimrud from 1860–63 and sent them to Zurich.
AD 1918-2010. British Assyriologist who worked on the British School of Archaeology in Iraq's excavations at Nimrud in the 1950s and published many of the cuneiform inscriptions found there.
Country house in the southern English county of Surrey, which in the late 19th century was home to the Wainwright family, who donated Assyrian bas-reliefs to the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge.
AD 1880–1960. British archaeologist, who led joint US-British excavations at the city of Ur in southern Mesopotamia from 1922–34. Employed the young Max Mallowan on the dig at Ur.
Ancient Greek historian, active on the early fourth century BC, who wrote about the recent Greek wars with Achaemenid Persia and thus also about earlier Middle Eastern history.
(meaning unknown, West Semitic name): queen of Assyria and wife of king Tiglath-pileser III, who was buried under the Northwest Palace at Kalhu.
District under the control of the provincial governor of Kalhu, location unknown.
Major mountain range running some 1,500 km from northeastern Iraq to the Persian Gulf; home to many tribes and kingdoms in Assyrian times.
Assyrian province on the northwestern slopes of the Zagros mountain range and its capital city of the same name; modern Sulaimaniya; also known as Mazamua.
Here is a definition.
